senses.de: to make or become distinct or apart
senses.ex: Let's separate the light clothes from the dark before washing them.

Tips.title: Physical Separation
Tips.description: Often describes separating objects or items based on characteristics.
Tips.example: Please separate the recyclables from the trash.

Tips.title: Process Orientation
Tips.description: Can imply a process or steps to sort things or people.
Tips.example: The teacher asked us to separate into groups according to our project topics.

senses.de: to disunite, to part, to divorce
senses.ex: After years of unhappiness, they decided to separate.

Tips.title: End of Union
Tips.description: Used to describe a wide range of disunions, not just in personal relationships.
Tips.example: The business partners decided to separate and go their own ways.

Tips.title: Euphemism
Tips.description: Sometimes used to delicately refer to a divorce or breakup.
Tips.example: My aunt and uncle are separating after 15 years of marriage.

Tips.title: Physical Space
Tips.description: Highlights being in different locations or spaces.
Tips.example: During the exam, each student had a separate desk.

Tips.title: Independent Existence
Tips.description: Shows something operates or exists independently from others.
Tips.example: The new company will function as a separate entity from the parent corporation.

senses.ex: It's hard to separate fact from fiction in his stories.

Tips.title: Intellectual Effort
Tips.description: Indicates differentiating or making distinctions in thought or analysis.
Tips.example: In science, it's crucial to separate observations from interpretations.

senses.de: to separate a substance into its components
senses.ex: The lab technician separated the blood into its components.

Tips.title: Extraction Process
Tips.description: Refers to dividing a mixture into basic parts for examination or use.
Tips.example: To study the samples, we must first separate the cells from the plasma.

Tips.title: Medical Context
Tips.description: In medicine, it often involves a precision specific to lab or clinical contexts.
Tips.example: The surgeon will separate the damaged tissue from the healthy tissue.

Detach.wordDefinition:
The words detach and separate both mean to pull or break something apart, but they are used in slightly different situations.

Detach describes taking something off or away from another thing. For example, you might detach a key from a keyring or detach a document from a larger file.

Detach is more specific and implies that two things were connected before, while separate is a more general term used to describe anything that is no longer together.

Disconnect.wordDefinition:
Disconnect means to separate or break a connection between two things, so they are no longer linked or communicating with each other.

For example, you disconnect a phone call, meaning you end the connection between yourself and the person you were talking to.

Disconnect applies to breaking connections, while separate applies to physically dividing or moving things apart.

Disengage.wordDefinition:
Disengage means to disconnect, detach or withdraw from something or someone. It typically refers to removing oneself from a situation or relationship.

For example, disengaging from a conversation, disengaging from a toxic relationship, or disengaging from a fight.

Disengage is used when referring to detaching oneself from a situation or relationship while separate is used when referring to dividing or splitting tangible objects or entities.

Distinguish.wordDefinition:
Distinguish means to recognize the difference between two or more things or to identify the unique qualities or characteristics of something.

For example, we might distinguish between two different types of birds, or we might distinguish between two similar but distinct ideas.

Distinguish is used when we want to identify differences or unique qualities between two or more things, while separate is used when we want to divide or split something into distinct parts or keep something apart from something else.

Divide.wordDefinition:
Divide means to break something into parts or portions, while separate means to set apart, detach, or isolate something.

For example, we divide an apple into equal pieces to share it among friends. On the other hand, we separate two different types of fruits or vegetables to store them separately as they may spoil each other.

Divide is used when we want to allocate or distribute something, while separate is used when we want to isolate or distinguish something.

Isolate.wordDefinition:
The words isolate and separate both mean to keep things apart from one another, but they have slightly different meanings.

Isolate usually means to keep something or someone alone or away from others, often for the purpose of protection or study.

For example, doctors might isolate a patient with a contagious disease to prevent it from spreading to others.

Isolate is used when the focus is on keeping something or someone protected or contained, while separate is used when the focus is on organizing or dividing different things or groups.

Segregate.wordDefinition:
Segregate means to keep things or people apart because of differences such as race or religion. It has negative connotations because it implies discrimination or prejudice.

For example, in the past, some schools would segregate students based on their race, which was unfair.

Segregate has negative connotations and implies discrimination, while separate is neutral and simply means dividing things or people into different groups.

Sift.wordDefinition:
Sift refers to the act of passing something through a sieve or other fine mesh to remove any lumps or impurities.

For example, you might sift flour before baking to remove any clumps.

Separate is applicable when you need to divide something into distinct groups, while sift is applicable when you need to remove any unwanted particles from something.

Split.wordDefinition:
Split also means to divide things into parts or groups, but it often implies a more forceful or dramatic separation.

For example, you might say that a piece of wood split in two when someone hit it with an ax. You might also say that a group of friends split up after a big fight, meaning that they no longer hang out together or have a close relationship.

Separate is a more general term that can refer to any kind of division, while split often implies a more intense or impactful separation.

quotes.Text: People who work for me know that family comes first. And I'm fortunate to have a family that is very supportive of the work I do, so I don't have to live two separate lives.
quotes.Title: American Vice President
quotes.Name: Kamala Harris

quotes.Text: You cannot separate your life and your music and your job; everything's linked.
quotes.Name: Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo

quotes.Text: Separating your profession from friendship is very difficult.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Athlete
quotes.Name: Lyoto Machida

quotes.Text: A lot of my personal life feels very separate from my music.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Julia Holter

quotes.Text: For many years, I supported the concept of separate states.
quotes.Title: South African Statesman
quotes.Name: F. W. de Klerk

quotes.Text: I have a very clear separation between my life and my work.
quotes.Title: English Comedian
quotes.Name: Lee Mack

quotes.Text: Never separate the life you live from the words you speak.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Paul Wellstone

quotes.Text: I try not to think of my life in terms of separation.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Ilhan Omar

quotes.Text: You should not separate your life from what you do.
quotes.Title: French Actress
quotes.Name: Jeanne Moreau

quotes.Text: When we separate music from life we get art.
quotes.Title: American Composer
quotes.Name: John Cage
